content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Based on these comments, there will be some interesting clashes between people who just code addition and people who attempt something far more complicated.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Difficult for CoC but i like the idea nice work :smile:

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: A bit difficult but nice..

I'm really divided on this one. I really like the puzzle; base conversion is always fun, but in this case it would be a trap, because unless you already really know how to write a decoder/encoder, this is really hard to pull off properly in less than 15 minutes. 

When I tried forgoing decoding entirely (by just replacing by the next symbol and carrying over as you go), it was a lot more manageable. Funny how the naive approach is often the fastest one for these!

That said, the statement is clear and well-formatted, and the test cases are very varied; I like this a lot. If this was any more complex (with maybe adding two different numbers for example instead of just +1), I think it would make a really nice classic puzzle.
Please don't use non-ASCII symbols (§). Some older languages do not handle them properly.

I first tried converting the symbols to digits and this converted string to a number before adding 1, but then I realized there was no built-in method to convert the value back to a general base n. I could have probably written that fairly quickly, but this was already 5 minutes in, and the problem is really a lot simpler than all that.

Changing strategies, I decided to increment the last digit myself, and just carry any overflow thru to the previous digit. If I had been able to do this in 5 minutes I would have passed it, and chalked up the lost time to poor planning. Surprisingly, it took me nearly another 10 minutes. Maybe I just wasn't thinking clearly?

My code still failed when the overflow should make the number longer. I was hoping to get away without. That turned out to be an easy fix, but it brought the total time to just over 15 minutes.

base = int(input())
digits = input()
revert = {n: each for n, each in enumerate(digits)}
convert = {each: n for n, each in enumerate(digits)}
number = list(input())
pos = len(number) - 1
while True:
    value = convert[number[pos]]
    value += 1
    overflow = value == base
    if overflow:
        value = 0
    number[pos] = revert[value]
    if overflow:
        pos -= 1
        if pos < 0:
            number = [revert[1]] + number
            break
    else:
        break
print(*number, sep='')

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: Too difficult to complete in 5 minutes.
great

I tried to make a lot of tests case to allow reverse mode. 
But still, I am not sure it would be feasible.

I agree it's too hard for reverse mode. But otherwise, nice contribution !
I liked your solution (I did something different).

Maybe I'm just having a bad day? This might be doable in 5 minutes with a focus on what actually needs to be done. But the discovery of what's needed only comes with the experience of doing it, no?

For a clash, you could simplify by leaving out the list of symbols. The base is at most 10, so just use digits 0 to at most 9. This should avoid a lot of unnecessary work, and make it much easier to think about how the increment needs to be performed.

Alternatively, leave the symbols but fix the base, if not decimal then maybe octal for a tiny bit of a challenge. This would allow a strategy of converting the entire value to and from. In fact, this clash could coexist with the above.

For a classic puzzle, on the other hand, include bases longer than 10. Heck, include bases longer than 10 + 26.

I am sorry to hear that.

I want to avoid built-in solutions.

I see two solutions:
- Either work backward adding 1 to last digit and carry any overflow to previous digit. This can be sped up by realizing that an overflow occurs only if current digit is the maximal digit.
- Or convert the number to internal representation add 1 and convert back.

You did in between. Converting each digit separately. Making your life harder ^^'

Answering you, I spotted a mistake in the test cases: Numbers should not start with zero. It will be easier for the conversion solution without them.

I added the conversion solution.

You are right '§' is not a ASCII symbol.
It was not intended.
I replaced it with '+'.
Maybe all that's needed is a hint. Adding 1 is a fairly simple operation that doesn't necessarily require converting the full value.
Thanks
Thanks :)

A challenge that adapt to the level of the developer ;)
Thanks :)

Should I add a hint to push toward carry from the low digit?
Both solutions seems fairly equal to me in term of difficulty.
Also the new "Long base" and "Long number" test cases push toward the carry over solution already.
You do make it look so easy!
But... It is :D

The symbols are the hearth of the problem.
You definitively can convert to and from with the problem like that.
Actually I will remove decimal and binary tests cases. They were there to allow reverse mode, but they will mislead into built-in solutions.
I will replace them with long basis and long numbers to guide better.
Removed reverse mode.
